column4: hello, im having a problem with installing ubuntu 64 bit.. i keep gettinga  long list of errors saying buffer I/O error on device fdo logical block 0 can anyone help me with this
https://answers.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+question/7697
https://answers.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+question/7697
nano
when nothing worked at all for me I checked the CD, the CD drive, the IDE cable ... I had a bad CD drive, as it turned out
first thing you'll need is the monitor's specs for vertical and horizontal ... what'sitcalled. refresh rate?
that's not the spec you're looking for
yes, most likely
look up your monitor's specs; you will find specs for vert and horiz sync
these will be in the form of ranges, for example, vertical sync 60-110 kHz (I made this up, check your actual specs)
yes
check that the backup exists: 'ls /etc/X11/xorg.*
thought you found them, 56-76Hz vertical, 30-83kHz horizontal?
the ranges are what you want (e.g., 56-76Hz if that was correct)
next you back up your xorg.conf file: In a terminal window, 'sudo cp /etc/X11/xorg.conf /etc/X11/xorg.conf.backup' (no quotes marks, and the X in X11 is capitalized)
check that the backup exists: 'ls /etc/X11/xorg.*'
are you needing to work working from a command line? or can you use a GUI editor like gedit for a bit?
you  can use nano instead of gedit and avoid the whole gui issue if need be
find Section "Monitor" and look for "Horizsync" and "VertRefresh" (they may not be there yet though)  -- find: Section "Monitor"
n/p - add them: HorizSync  (and the range of horizontal sync you looked up) and then VertRefresh (and the vert ref. you looked up)
HorizSync and VertRefresh - the capitalization doesn't matter but the spelling does
ctl-alt-f1 will take you to a console
I think it's ctl-o to write out your changed file ... should be prompts at bottom of screen
